results.title: Boxing for boys: attack, defence and ringcraft
results.creator_credit: Frank Wells, Gaumont-British Instructional and Colin Bell
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the chief form of attack and defence; section of the glove to be used in hitting, portion of the body to be hit; correct stance; the straight left; the right hook; the swing; a lead and an uppercut; side stepping; the cross counter; the parry, blocking; slipping and ducking.

results.title: Boxes...boxes...boxes
results.creator_credit: Robin Dove, Coincidence Productions and Sue Wilson
results.brief_description: Shows a highschool “art event” at Hyde Park, Sydney. Includes the human sandwich, capturing space in boxes, man’s ordered existence, a 50 foot long piece of weaving, and seeing the environment from a new viewpoint.

results.title: Boxes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Mary Anna Winkler, Peter Erik Winkler and ACI Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “At Your Fingertips”.
Shows a number of things that can be made by children from boxes which originally held house-hold items. Cereal boxes covered with paper and coloured become a model village; milk cartons are made into cars or trains or animals. The biggest cartons, such as those in which refrigerators are delivered, appear as a truck, with two boys as the motive power, delivering to a playhouse. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: Boxcar Bertha
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman, American International Pictures (AIP) and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: Set in the Depression era of the late 1920s, Scorsese’s first studio feature film is a spirited and deftly executed gangster drama. Barbara Hershey plays Bertha, a young woman who on becoming homeless during the Depression, joins an itinerant group of unemployed travellers. Jumping from train to train, she makes box-cars her home and is introduced to socialist politics by her lover, Big Bill Shelley (David Carradine). When the police and state, acting with a deliberate cruelty, attempt to break apart the delicate communities built by the unemployed Bertha and Big Bill become train robbers: on an ironic take of the Robin Hood legend, they steal from the rich and they give it to the Trade Unions. Working within the strict budgetary confines of Roger Corman’s B-grade exploitation genre, Scorsese illuminates a fairly conventional gangster narrative with a glowing romanticism. In some of the more violent sequences, and in particular the highly charged climax, the film introduces themes that are to be continuing concerns for Scorsese over the length of his controversial career. Based on the memoirs of Boxcar Bertha herself.

results.title: Box kite to swing wing
results.brief_description: A history of the Royal Australian Air Force from the original Australian Flying Corps to todays modern aircraft of Macchi jet trainers, medium range Hercules and Iriquois helicopters. Shows their operations in World Wars I and II, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam plus their peacetime operations.

results.title: Bowling for Columbine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dog Eat Dog Films, Salter Street Films, VIF 2, Jim Czarnecki, Kathleen Glynn and Michael Moore
results.brief_description: Michael Moore’s 2002 documentary came in the wake of the burgeoning fame and infamy that the social and media commentator, agent provocateur, satirist and political activist garnered with his television series, “The Awful truth” and publications including “Stupid white men”. In this work Moore addresses the problem of violence in America, focusing on gun culture, the prevalence of gun ownership and the sanctity of the American right to bear arms. Moore’s approach is to interview a variety of people attempting to depict a tapestry that may explain America’s relationship to guns. Among his interviewees are student survivors of the 1999 Columbine school massacre, National Rifle Association spokesperson and actor, Charlton Heston, politicians, police and various gun enthusiasts. Moore tries to dispel myths that are propagated as an explanation as to why American society is so at war with itself - its bloody history, the volume of guns amid the population, violence in the media, American’s preponderance for violent video games and films. Moore questions these theories by focusing on other less violent countries with these same qualities. One of Moore’s strongest theories is that the scare-mongering prevalent in society, broadcast through the media, and the popularity of reality TV shows, such as “COPS”, promotes the notion that danger is omnipresent to the individual and must be countered. Winner of Best Documentary at the 2003 Academy Awards, Moore’s acceptance speech earned him even greater notoriety when he criticised US President Bush and the war on Iraq.

results.title: Bowling action
results.creator_credit: Realist Films, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids, Brian Smith, Dorothy Grayson and Denys Parsons
results.brief_description: An analysis of the slow-medium bowling action of Ray Smith of Essex. The movements of Smith’s body in a run-up and delivery are shown and analysed, using normal speed, slow motion, and suspended shots. At four key positions of the action, H.P. Crabtree illustrates a method by which boys can obtain concentrated practice in pitching the ball for both length and direction. Commentary by John Arlott and filmed on location at Lord’s (MCC), the home of cricket.
